render_latex

Convenience function to print $\LaTeX$ text in Jupyter Notebook code (as opposed to markdown) cells. The purpose is to print $\LaTeX$ content that is only known at run time. Font size of every formula is increased (to \Large)

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

render_latex[source]

render_latex(text:str)

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
render_latex('Bla blah...')

Bla blah...

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
render_latex('Variable $A$')

Variable $\Large A$

{% endraw %}

Accessors

Pandas's accessors mechanishm is leveraged here. In order to do that, first Pandas' _register_accessor method was aliased above as simply register_accessor. Then a new base class, AccessorEndowedClass, from which any class exposing an accessor must inherit, is created. The only thing it does is adding a class attribute that is expected by Pandas' _register_accessor method.

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class AccessorEndowedClass[source]

AccessorEndowedClass()

{% endraw %}

For instance

{% raw %} 
class Car(AccessorEndowedClass):
    
    def __init__(self, weight):
        
        self.weight = weight

@register_accessor('seat', Car)
class SeatAccessor:
    
    def __init__(self, car: Car):
        
        self._confortable: bool = True
    
    @property
    def confortable(self):
        
        return self._confortable
{% endraw %}

Accessing the class itself

{% raw %} 
car = Car(1600)
car.weight

1600
{% endraw %}

Accessing the appended accessor

{% raw %} 
car.seat.confortable

True
{% endraw %}

Assorted

A function to turn an integer into a roman number. Taken from here.

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

int_to_roman[source]

int_to_roman(num:int)

Returns an integer number in roman format.

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
print(int_to_roman(53))

LIII
{% endraw %}

Files

dict_to_yaml

A function to write a dictionary to a YAML file with some formatting.

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

dict_to_yaml[source]

dict_to_yaml(d:dict, output_file:Union[str, Path])

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
yaml_file = '_test.yaml'
d = {'foo': 1, 'ouch': 'psss'}
dict_to_yaml(d, yaml_file)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
%pycat {yaml_file}

foo: 1
ouch: psss
{% endraw %}

yaml_to_dict

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

yaml_to_dict[source]

yaml_to_dict(file:Union[str, Path])

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
yaml_to_dict(yaml_file)

{'foo': 1, 'ouch': 'psss'}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
%rm {yaml_file}
{% endraw %}

write_multiple_categories

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

write_multiple_categories[source]

write_multiple_categories(category_questions:Dict[str, List[dict]], pictures_base_directory:str, output_file:str='out.yaml')

Writes a file suitable as input to gift-wrapper.

Parameters

category_questions : dict Every key is the name of a category, and every value is a list of questions (every question is itself a dictionary). pictures_base_directory : str The "pictures base directory" parameter that must be passed to gift-wrapper output_file : str Output file

{% endraw %}

We build a dictionary with questions belonging different categories. This might be read from a YAML file.

{% raw %} 
category_questions_example = {
    ('Category A', 'Category B'): [
        {
            'class': 'MultipleChoice',
            'statement': 'Compute the entropy....\n',
            'feedback': 'We just need to...\n',
            'time': '3',
            'answers': {
                'perfect': '1',
                'wrong': ['0', '2']
            },
            'name': 'Entropy of a random variable I'
        }
    ],
    'Category C': [
        {
            'class': 'Numerical',
            'statement': 'Compute the average....\n',
            'feedback': 'In order to...\n',
            'time': '3',
            'solution': {
                'value': 3.1,
                'error': '10%'
            }, 
            'name': 'Mean energy I'
        }
    ]
}
category_questions_example

{('Category A',
  'Category B'): [{'class': 'MultipleChoice',
   'statement': 'Compute the entropy....\n',
   'feedback': 'We just need to...\n',
   'time': '3',
   'answers': {'perfect': '1', 'wrong': ['0', '2']},
   'name': 'Entropy of a random variable I'}],
 'Category C': [{'class': 'Numerical',
   'statement': 'Compute the average....\n',
   'feedback': 'In order to...\n',
   'time': '3',
   'solution': {'value': 3.1, 'error': '10%'},
   'name': 'Mean energy I'}]}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
output_file = '_output.yaml'
write_multiple_categories(category_questions_example, 'pics', output_file)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
%cat {output_file}

pictures base directory: pics
categories:
  - name:
      - Category A
      - Category B
    questions:
      - class: MultipleChoice
        statement: "Compute the entropy....\n"
        feedback: "We just need to...\n"
        time: '3'
        answers:
          perfect: '1'
          wrong:
            - '0'
            - '2'
        name: Entropy of a random variable I
  - name: Category C
    questions:
      - class: Numerical
        statement: "Compute the average....\n"
        feedback: "In order to...\n"
        time: '3'
        solution:
          value: 3.1
          error: 10%
        name: Mean energy I
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
!rm {output_file}
{% endraw %}

File system

A small utility function to derive a file path by appending something to the name (and only to the name).

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

supplement_file_name[source]

supplement_file_name(file:Union[str, Path], sup:str)

Adds a string between the file name in a path and the suffix.

Parameters

file : str File name sup : str String to be added

Returns

out: pathlib.Path "Supplemented" file

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
supplement_file_name('/a/b/picture.tex', '1')

PosixPath('/a/b/picture_1.tex')
{% endraw %}

Question-related

add_name

Adds a name to every question in a list based on a pattern. It is meant to distinctly name different versions of the same question. Notice that, for this function, a question is simply a dictionary (no checks are performed).

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

add_name[source]

add_name(questions:List[dict], base_name:str)

Adds a name to every question based on a pattern.

Parameters

questions : list List of questions; every question is a dictionary. question_base_name : str All the questions will be given this name and a different (Roman) number.

Returns

out: list List with the same questions after adding the corresponding name to each one.

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
add_name([{'k1': 'aa', 'k2': 1}, {'k3': 'pi', 'foo': 'variance'}], 'base')

[{'k1': 'aa', 'k2': 1, 'name': 'base I'},
 {'k3': 'pi', 'foo': 'variance', 'name': 'base II'}]
{% endraw %}

Get wrong solutions from the correct one

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

wrong_numerical_solutions_from_correct_one[source]

wrong_numerical_solutions_from_correct_one(solution:float, n:int, min_sep:float, max_sep:float, lower_bound:float=-inf, upper_bound:float=inf, precision:int=4, to_str:bool=True, fixed_point_format:bool=False, bin_width:Optional[float]=None, unique:bool=False, prng:RandomState=RandomState(MT19937) at 0x7F9EA1B5C140)

Generates random numerical wrong answers given the correct one.

Parameters

solution: float The actual solution. n: int The number of wrong solutions. min_sep: float Minimum separation. max_sep: float Maximum separation. lower_bound: float, optional A lower bound on the returned numbers. upper_bound: float, optional A upper bound on the returned numbers. precision: int, optional The number of decimal places. to_str: bool, optional If True, every element in the result will be converted to a string. fixed_point_format: bool Only meaningful when to_str is True. In such case, if True a fixed-point format (f) is used regardless of the actual type. bin_width: float, optional The granularity on the answers: every one will be a multiple of this parameter. unique: bool, optional If True, all the answers will be different. prng: RandomState, optional A pseudo-random numbers generator.

Returns

out: list of float, or list of str The random wrong solutions.

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
wrong_numerical_solutions_from_correct_one(solution=0.8, n=10, min_sep=0.1, max_sep=0.5, lower_bound=0.2, upper_bound=2, prng = np.random.RandomState(42))

['1.14',
 '1.193',
 '1.05',
 '0.9232',
 '0.3535',
 '0.4168',
 '0.4605',
 '0.3197',
 '0.9624',
 '0.6376']
{% endraw %}

Numbers instead of strings

{% raw %} 
wrong_numerical_solutions_from_correct_one(
    solution=0.8, n=4, min_sep=0.2, max_sep=0.5, lower_bound=0.2, upper_bound=0.9, to_str=False,
    prng = np.random.RandomState(42))

[0.3148, 0.4204, 0.5532, 0.3401]
{% endraw %}

If the solution cannot be anything, you might want to pass a bin_width so that it doesn't immediately stand out from the wrong answers,

{% raw %} 
wrong_numerical_solutions_from_correct_one(
    solution=0.8, n=8, min_sep=0.1, max_sep=2, lower_bound=0.2, upper_bound=2, to_str=False, bin_width=0.1,
    prng = np.random.RandomState(42))

[1.1, 1.5, 0.2, 0.6, 1.5, 1.2, 1.9, 1.9]
{% endraw %}

If duplicates must be avoided unique can be set to True,

{% raw %} 
wrong_numerical_solutions_from_correct_one(
    solution=0.8, n=8, min_sep=0.1, max_sep=2, lower_bound=0.2, upper_bound=2, to_str=False, bin_width=0.1,
    unique=True, prng = np.random.RandomState(42))

[1.0, 1.2, 1.5, 0.7, 0.6, 0.2, 1.9, 1.1]
{% endraw %}

Lower and upper bound can be ommited

{% raw %} 
wrong_numerical_solutions_from_correct_one(
    solution=0.8, n=8, min_sep=0.5, max_sep=10, to_str=False, bin_width=0.1, unique=True,
    prng = np.random.RandomState(42))

[6.4, -8.9, 9.5, -1.7, -6.8, 7.3, -8.3, 2.7]
{% endraw %}

When requesting strings, a floating point format can be enforced by using the parameter fixed_point_format,

{% raw %} 
wrong_numerical_solutions_from_correct_one(
    solution=0.8, n=8, min_sep=0.5, max_sep=10, to_str=True, fixed_point_format=True, bin_width=0.1, unique=True,
    prng = np.random.RandomState(42))

['6.4000',
 '-8.9000',
 '9.5000',
 '-1.7000',
 '-6.8000',
 '7.3000',
 '-8.3000',
 '2.7000']
{% endraw %}
